title: London's 'poisoned lungs' revealed: survey shows quarter of green spaces are now dangerously polluted
text:
Escaping to the park or allotment for some invigorating fresh air is strongly encouraged by doctors as a means of keeping healthy.

However, a new study suggests that spending time in urban green spaces exposes people to high levels of potentially dangerous pollution.

A highly detailed analysis of air quality in London found that more than a quarter of the city’s parks, playgrounds and open spaces exceed international safety limits.

Twenty-four per cent of play spaces and 27 per cent of public parks had nitrogen dioxide (N02) levels above the European threshold.

The joint study by Imperial College London (ICL) and the University of Leicester also found that 67 per cent of private parks - often situated in squares surrounded by tall buildings - were unsafe.

NO2 is predominantly emitted by vehicles, but also from wood-burning stoves and commercial sources.

The data for the capital, which is likely to broadly reflect other polluted cities in the UK, was compiled by applying 2011 census data to 2016 readings from the London Atmospheric Emissions Inventory, which breaks down into 20ms zones.

Five of the 10 most polluted parks were found in to be in the borough of Westminster, and the the worst air quality was in Victoria Embankment Gardens, whose NO2 annual average was 59.7 µg/m3, followed by Parliament Square Gardens, which was 58.7 µg/m3.
